title: Infrastructure 'far better' than any one-off stimulus
text:
Mullen knows a thing or two about infrastructure having spent about 35 years working in senior positions in transport and logistics including eight years as chief executive of ports and rail operator Asciano. He is a director of Brookfield Infrastructure Partners and executive chairman of Toll Group.

“I'm very supportive of investment in infrastructure, having spent half my life in related industries,” he said in an interview with Chanticleer.

“I think the advantage of investing in infrastructure is you both get the stimulus and you also get a long-term asset with it that will continue to add to growth, which is far better than any one-off stimulus you could put into the market.”

Mullen said there was no shortage of opportunity for government assisted infrastructure investment given the strong population growth and the slow decision making over many decades in relation to critical infrastructure connections.

“There's an awful lot that can be done,” he says.

“I think the challenge we have is the infrastructure cycles are long. They tend to be 10 to 20-year type cycles, whereas electoral cycles are very short, which is never an incentive for any government, state or federal, to spend a lot of money and see successors two decades later reap the benefits.

“Somehow we really could have some political unity on both sides to make these long-term decisions that are fundamental to Australia.”

Mullen said the amount of savings being generated through the compulsory superannuation system meant there were funds available to invest. But there needed to be some sort of incentive to invest.

“I think some form of government incentive around trying to direct a percentage of those super investments into infrastructure with attractive tax treatments is an extremely good idea,” he said.

Telstra chairman John Mullen. Nick Moir

“I don't know why the government would not embrace that.”

Mullen stopped short of endorsing a special infrastructure fund financed with the issue of government bonds. He said it was up to the experts to decide what was the optimal way to encourage more infrastructure investment.

The incoming president of the Business Council of Australia, Tim Reed, said the pressure should be on the state governments rather than the federal government when it came to encouraging infrastructure investment.

Also, he said it was essential governments carry some of the risks involved in infrastructure investment.

“I think the first thing to recognise is that much of that infrastructure comes through the states and you know, and the federal government certainly encourage it,” he said.

“Joe Hockey [former Treasurer] did that with the asset recycling program, and that seemed to work well. I think the government should go back and look at what worked well, before and, we’d certainly encourage them to think about extending that program."

Reed said the NSW government understood that infrastructure investment was part of driving productivity growth.

“We would absolutely encourage state governments to continue to prioritise infrastructure and to look at continuing to build more infrastructure, whether they have to do that by taking on public debt or whether they can do that through recycling the assets that they've got,” he said.

He said complaints from government that additional infrastructure investment was not possible because of a skills shortage merely highlighted the need for increased vocational training.

“That gets back to our number one priority, right? – that we need to be making sure that Australians have the skills to be able to continue to contribute to growing productivity going forward."
description: Leading business figures have rallied around the idea of governments encouraging more investment in infrastructure. But there's a deafening silence from politicians.
